image.altText: a man wearing a grey shirt and blue jeans stepping into an empty cool room

props.synopsis: A remote Northern Territory community that has been cut off by flood damage now faces running out of food within a week, after six weeks without enough to go around.

title.children: Food shortage in remote NT community leaves some 'having to hunt cattle'

image.altText: Thousands of used tyres in piles spread out over a brown landscape.

props.synopsis: While some used tyres end up being recycled, a growing amount are ending up in landfill or being illegally dumped, like this huge stockpile that has been left in a field.

title.children: 'Last thing community wants to see': Fight to stop used tyres being illegally dumped

image.altText: A selfie picture of man and woman at night with colourful lights under a water fountain behind them

props.synopsis: Ten days after Taiwan's earthquake trapped people inside Taroko National Park, three people remain unaccounted-for, including Australian-Sinaporean couple Sim Hwee Kok and Neo Siew Choo.

title.children: Two Australians wandered into Taiwan’s Mysterious Valley Trail. Then came a disaster

image.altText: A view of Jewel casino across Vila Bay at Iririki Resort, with hibiscus flowers in the foreground.

props.synopsis: The Jewel casino once stood at the turquoise shores of Vanuatu's Iririki Island — until its new owners shut it down. Their reason? "The house always wins."

title.children: Two Australian businessmen bought a casino in a tropical paradise — only to shut it down

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and glasses walks down a street.

props.synopsis: Despite distracting allegations, there's really only one thing anyone wants to know from the decision in the Bruce Lehrmann defamation case: does the judge think, on the balance of probabilities, Bruce Lehrmann raped Brittany Higgins?

title.children: As the judgment in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation trial approaches, one question rings out loudest

image.altText: the back of a man's head with traffic lights in the background

props.synopsis: A growing number of Aboriginal people are being struck and killed on Northern Territory roads. Indigenous leaders are sounding the alarm.

title.children: The NT has the highest rate of pedestrian deaths. One in four drivers doesn't stop

image.altText: NT Police Commissioner Michael Murphy standing at a lectern and looking up.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory chief minister says 25 police officers will temporarily relocate to Alice Springs until the end of June to provide support after the youth curfew lifts on Tuesday.

title.children: NT Police to send 25 extra officers to Alice Springs when curfew lifts

image.altText: Police walk along a street at night.

props.synopsis: Crime is just one symptom of the intractable tragedies unfolding in Central Australia. But as the media obsesses over this "crisis", the deeper issues are ignored, and it's First Nations communities that suffer.

title.children: While headlines shout about youth crime in Alice Springs, the greater danger lies beneath the surface

image.altText: Alcohol bottles on sand

props.synopsis: The NT government opened expressions of interest for the voluntary buy-back of grocery store liquor licences but has so far been unsuccessful striking a deal with Alice Springs operators.

title.children: 'It's an addiction, not a choice': Calls to reduce bottle shops in Alice Springs

image.altText: Eva Lawler wears a red jacket and looks seriously in front of her. She is in NT Parliament.

props.synopsis: Chief Minister Eva Lawler has told a Senate inquiry that a $1.5 billion federally funded industrial precinct may include petrochemical processing. Both the NT and federal government previously denied petrochemicals would feature at the proposed Darwin hub.

title.children: NT chief minister 'won't rule out' including petrochemicals at $1.5b industrial hub

image.altText: Two TAFE apprentice chefs cook in the kitchen.

props.synopsis: Restaurant owners may soon have to look locally for chefs if the federal government follows through on its 'skill-first' migration shake-up.

title.children: Chefs could be on the chopping block in migration shake-up

image.altText: Virginia Trioli pulls a weight machine towards her as she sits, smiling, in workout gear

props.synopsis: In the middle of a bushfire emergency, I tripped and sustained an injury that would deliver a sobering lesson in the universal experience of ageing. It was time to start taking care of my bones — by lifting heavy weights.

title.children: A scary fall in an emergency was a sobering reminder that ageing happens to all of us — yes, even you

image.altText: A still from Bluey showing Bluey next to Muffin, Bingo and Socks. The last three wear flower crowns

props.synopsis: A cliffhanger of an episode last week had some Bluey fans worried about the show's future. A produce says the 28-minute special is the "most beautiful" episode they've done.

title.children: Bluey isn't ending, but Sunday's special will get emotional. Here's what we know about it

image.altText: A colourful cartoon house with a For Sale sign out the front.

props.synopsis: Australia's favourite family appear to be on the move, but the hilarity and warmth that Bluey provides are in stark contrast to the reality of a housing crisis that's making life difficult for families like the Heelers. And yes, I'm aware they're a fictional family of cartoon dogs.

title.children: Bluey's family might be selling their house. What does it mean that they couldn't afford to buy it?

image.altText: A close up of a Black woman wearing a yellow shirt and beanie with her hands folded in front of her.

props.synopsis: When a woman was accused of using witchcraft in PNG to kill a young boy, she was attacked and left for dead. She survived thanks to the help of strangers and a safe house offering refuge for victims of sorcery-related violence.

title.children: When a death is hard to comprehend here, it can spark a murderous witch hunt

image.altText: Hannah Clarke, hugs her son Trey Baxter, while standing on a beach.

props.synopsis: It's a practice used by abusers which puts their victims lives at risk. Around the country, states and territories are taking steps to educate and legislate against the issue.

title.children: Coercive control is insidious and costing lives. Here's what's being done around the country to combat it

image.altText: Closed off street by police after Doonside stabbing 120424

props.synopsis: A 16-year-old boy will appear in court today charged with murder after two teenagers were stabbed, one fatally, in Sydney's west yesterday.

title.children: 16yo boy charged with murder after fatal stabbing near school in Sydney's west

image.altText: Nigel sitting in his backyard.

props.synopsis: These men have all badly hurt a partner or relative. They've even done time for it, but can they change for good? The ABC has been given exclusive access to a program that is helping them turn their lives around.

title.children: The Alice Springs courthouse sends violent men to prison. Inside a building across the road, they learn how to stay free

image.altText: Composite of a man with archival newspaper clippings and old photographs behind him.

props.synopsis: Gehamat Loban didn't set out to make history when he left his island home at 14 but he and 70 others from the Torres Strait Islands did just that with a world record that still stands today.

title.children: These Torres Strait Islanders broke a world record. Their story has largely gone untold, until now

image.altText: A crop of a square video, showing a blonde woman wearing a dark blue flak jacket.

props.synopsis: A UNICEF aid worker recounts the moment her aid convoy, which had informed both parties in the Israel-Gaza conflict of its movements, was hit by bullets in Gaza.

title.children: Australian aid worker's convoy hit by bullets while delivering aid in Gaza

image.altText: Side by side photos of Peter Dutton giving a speech and Penny Wong looking serious

props.synopsis: If Palestinians feel unloved by both Israel and Hamas in Gaza, their family and friends in Australia feel equally unloved by our major political parties.

title.children: Arab and Muslim voters in Australia feel unheard by our major parties

image.altText: A drawing of a wombat with a runner's number and singlet breaking through a red finish line ribbon

props.synopsis: It's claimed a wombat can beat any human over 100 metres. Now, an exhaustive ABC investigation has tracked down the truth of the 40kph sprinting wombat myth.

title.children: How fast can wombats run? We dug into the truth of claims they can beat Usain Bolt

image.altText: Composite image

props.synopsis: There are reports of people having to be helped from their cars as heavy rainfall causes chaos in Perth's northern suburbs.

title.children: Shopping centre ceiling caves and people helped from flooded cars as Perth freak storm wreaks havoc

image.altText: nickelback hate to love

props.synopsis: Nickelback had a chance to own the narrative around why they're so hated with their official documentary. Instead, they double-down on their formulaic approach to keeping their fans entertained.

title.children: Nickelback are 'the most hated band in the world'. Their new documentary won't win them any new fans

image.altText: A lady riding a white horse on a beach

props.synopsis: For women setting out to explore the world by themselves, adventure is calling, along with a growing sense of self discovery. Here's a taste of solo travel from the eyes of three Aussies.

title.children: 'A liberating feeling': Why women are taking the solo travel leap and how to prepare for the trip

image.altText: Two men, a woman and two children stand at a gate

props.synopsis: Liberals' candidate for the seat of Cook, Simon Kennedy, won't be able to personally boost voter turnout as his team confirmed he didn't move into the electorate in time to meet the registration deadline.

title.children: Liberal candidate to replace Scott Morrison can't vote for himself in tonight's by-election

image.altText: A close-up shot of Donald Trump's face, with an annoyed expression.

props.synopsis: Former president Donald Trump urges Arizona politicians to swiftly "remedy" the state Supreme Court ruling allowing prosecutors to enforce a near-total abortion ban that he declares "went too far."

title.children: Trump pushes Arizona politicians to 'remedy' state abortion ruling that he says 'went too far'

image.altText: Three teens perch behind a car, bent over and spying on someone. They all are lowering their sunglasses for a closer look.

props.synopsis: Netflix's reboot of the 90s classic is celebrated for its diverse characters and plots. Its cast discuss how season two engages with criticism that it's "too woke".

title.children: Heartbreak High takes on our 'crisis of masculinity' — but with 'plenty of piss-takes' in season two

image.altText: Roberto Cavalli is pictured wearing a black jacket and white shirt while standing with his arms crossed. Behind him are crowns.

props.synopsis: Italian fashion designer Roberto Cavalli, whose penchant for python and flamboyant animal prints made him the darling of the international jet set for decades, died Friday at 83, news media said.

title.children: Italian designer Roberto Cavalli dies aged 83

image.altText: A young blonde woman smiling in a matching houndstooth beret and blazer.

props.synopsis: Liz Sunshine spends more time thinking about the way we dress than most. But her shopping advice is simple: "Slow down."

title.children: 'Now I shop less than ever': A fashion photographer on becoming a more sustainable shopper

image.altText: emergency services at night outside a rural property

props.synopsis: Police were called to the property at Kilkivan on Friday afternoon after reports of a fight between two men.

title.children: Police shoot 42-year-old man after fatal stabbing near Gympie, Queensland

image.altText: An elderly woman standing next to a house in flood waters up to her waist.

props.synopsis: Thousands of people have been evacuated from the Orenburg region as warming temperatures cause heavy snow to melt.

title.children: Melting snow forces thousands from their homes in flooded Russian city

image.altText: A person carrying a box walks past piled displays of vegetables

props.synopsis: Australians are eating less of all major food groups, with fresh produce leading the decline, says a new report.

title.children: Australians are consuming less fruit, vegetables and milk — here's what that looks like
